Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Developing a Minor Program in Applied Statistics within the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at Fort Valley State University.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. Fort Valley State University will implement a Targeted Infusion Project entitled: Developing a Minor Program in Applied Statistics within the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science. The project is designed to develop students' statistical knowledge and thinking through activities that require scientific and data driven decision making processes; improve enrollment and retention of students in STEM fields by enhancing enrollment and retention in statistics; engage students in mentor supervised research in areas related to statistics applications; and enhance learning, teaching and research capabilities through the use of new instructional technologies and methodologies.

The project team will enhance an existing course with interdisciplinary activities and projects and develop five new courses for the minor in Applied Statistics curriculum within the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science. Courses to be developed will cover topics in applied methods in regression, key concepts of biostatistics including mathematical modeling and computational simulation techniques, methods of constructing and designing statistical experiments, time series, and nonparametric statistics. Curriculum development efforts will be complemented with faculty mentoring, summer research internships, and peer-to-peer advising.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Six Applied Statistics courses that addressed the Applied Statistics curriculum beyond Elementary Statistics had been developed allowing students at Fort Valley State University (an HBCU with about 3000 students) to graduate from their majors with an added bonus made possible by this project: a Minor in Applied Statistics. Some of these courses have also been used as electives for students who did not necessarily wish to complete all requirements of a minor but wanted to enhance their statistics and data analysis experience before they join the real world workforce as well as for their undergraduate research experience in Biology, Chemistry, Engineering, Computer Science and Information Systems and other areas.  Between the beginning of spring 2016 and the end of spring 2017 (three academic year semesters), five of the six newly developed courses had been offered and two students completed the requirements for a minor in applied statistics. A third student completed four of the five courses required for a minor in applied statistics.

Although the main purpose of the project was to develop a minor program in applied statistics within the department of mathematics and computer science by developing six applied statistics courses, the program had components that complemented towards the main purpose. Among these components were a yearly summer camp dubbed “Math and Science Summer Bridge” that targeted incoming freshmen, sponsored undergraduate researches in areas that used statistics and its applications, and peer tutoring in basic mathematics and statistics courses. Over the life of the grant (three years), 40 students received certificate of completion from the Math and Science Summer Bridge for completing approximately 45 hours of lessons in introductory content, hands-on activities, technology usage and/or laboratory experience in Mathematics, Applied Statistics, Biology, Chemistry, Physics and Nuclear Science and Engineering. About six instructional facilitators, two counselors and an adult supervisor also participated in the Bridge each year.  About 23 students and 11 faculty mentors had been supported for undergraduate research experience. About a combined 460 hours of tutoring have been supported by the grant.  The grant also supported travel and lodging for the PI and Co-PIs to participate in professional conferences and HBCU-UP annual meetings.  Products of the project also include 6 papers published on   Journal or Conference proceedings where the PI or Co-PI had collaborated as authors or co-authors. Due to this project, an old mathematics research laboratory has also been upgraded to a mathematics and statistics laboratory equipped with MatLab and R/RStudio.
